comment: Completed CS-229 on march 5th 2024 16:53 IST. started it on Jan 1st 2024. Thoroughly enjoyed these lectures and the notes . Though these were on the harder side I enjoyed the mathematical content.   Just some small suggestions -: 1. First just read the lecture notes of the perticular topic and then see the lecture it helps 2. after hearing the lecture using the lecture notes make your own notes 3.  If u find a lecture tough take a day gap and come back to it or skip that lecture and go back to it later
Thank you professor Adnrew and Stanford Online for this great course.
Finished 😌
Hey guys, if you've made it here, please share your insights about this series. I've just started and would love to hear from those who have completed this class.
Really very cool!! Thank you.

haha, i love this course so much. Thanks to Youtube Stanford Andrew and all of the related parties <3.
Not entirely linear or straightforward, but also not entirely Byzantine. A good man and a good teacher.

The number of comments reduced to 8 only....just completed this course in more than 3 months....
1.3 million people started but people who ended these are the real winners, you are the winner

You know, maybe I'm foolish, but if I had to make a cart on a rail keep an inverted pendulum up, I would solve the physics problem and build the solution around that.  If it knows where it is and how fast it's going and where the pendulum is and how fast it's going, it knows everything and should be able to plan and execute an entire trajectory.  It seems to me the only way you'd need "control" would be to account for noise in measurement inaccuracies.  It would "plan" the entire future dynamics of the thing and then simply execute it.
So who decides what's "judgment" and what's "gut feel"?  ;-)
